channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: On the Ground in Syria: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Iraq Protesters Storm Parliament, Demanding End to Corruption
item.media:description: Followers of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr stormed Baghdad’s Green Zone Saturday, gleefully slipping past barricades and barbed wire, after lawmakers failed to convene for a vote on overhauling the government.
item.description: Hundreds breached the razor wire of Baghdad’s fortified Green Zone, long seen as a symbol of a government detached from ordinary Iraqi citizens.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN, OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Partial Truce Said to Be Restored in Syria, but Not Yet in Aleppo
item.media:description: Syrians evacuating an injured man after an airstrike in Aleppo on Friday.
item.description: The United States and Russia said they had won agreement for a new partial truce after a bloody week, but that it would not immediately include Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)

item.title: Debt Collectors Adopt Mob Tactics as Russians Struggle to Pay Bills
item.media:description: A currency exchange office in Moscow in January. In March, for the first time since 2008, Russians spent over half their income on food, beverages and cigarettes, according to government statistics, and more people are resorting to borrowing at astronomical interest rates.
item.description: A culture of violence and threats flourishes as growing numbers of Russians turn to borrowing at astronomical interest rates amid a recession.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Photo of Paris Massacre Victim Sets Off Press Freedom Case
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.description: A photographer who sold a picture of a man who later died has been charged under a strict French right-to-privacy law.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Muslim’s Labour Candidacy Shapes London Mayoral Race
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, the Labour Party candidate in London’s mayoral election on Thursday, posed for photos last month outside New Scotland Yard.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: With Britain struggling to integrate minorities, Sadiq Khan is favored to win election on Thursday, which would make him the first Muslim to lead the city and give a boost to his opposition party.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Inquiry Into Missing Mexican Students Ends on Note of Frustration
item.description: Foreign investigators and the government battled each other with dueling news conferences in the inquiry’s final week.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Honduras Fires Over Two Dozen Police Commanders
item.description: A purge intended to clean up the force complemented an effort by President Juan Orlando Hernández to bypass the national police in favor of a militarized force.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Nepal’s Earthquake Recovery Remains in Disarray a Year Later
item.media:description: A building in Kathmandu, Nepal, still needed to be supported by poles on Monday, the one-year anniversary of the day it was damaged in an earthquake that killed almost 9,000 people.
item.description: The government, hampered by red tape and political turmoil, is unable to take full advantage of $4.1 billion in aid, and some donors are growing restless.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Antismoking Coalition Gives Big Tobacco a Fight in Indonesia
item.media:description: Philip Morris International painted houses in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, as part of its “Show Your Colors” advertising campaign.
item.media:credit: Justin Mott for The New York Times
item.description: Funding from the Bloomberg Initiative is building local opposition to companies that have eagerly expanded in one of the largest cigarette markets in Asia.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT

item.title: China Blocks U.S. Navy Flotilla’s Visit to Hong Kong
item.description: The rare refusal to allow entry into the port comes as the United States challenges the Chinese government’s claims in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Kenya Burns Elephant Ivory Worth $105 Million to Defy Poachers
item.media:description: Seized ivory burning in Kenya on Saturday. “No one, and I repeat, no one, has any business in trading in ivory, for this trade means death — the death of our elephants and the death of our natural heritage,” Mr. Kenyatta declared.
item.description: It was the most ivory ever destroyed at one time, representing 6,000 to 7,000 dead elephants.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: In Congo, Wars Are Small and Chaos Is Endless
item.media:description: Members of the Bambote ethnic group in an abandoned cotton factory in Nyunzu, Democratic Republic of Congo. The Bambote are forest dwellers who have been displaced by one of the many violent conflicts in Congo.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: Traditional forest dwellers, known for their capacity to cooperate, have become embroiled in and displaced by one of the conflicts that typify the Democratic Republic of Congo as an election crisis looms.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Rouhani Backers Gain Iran Parliamentary Seats, but Not Majority
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani has faced resistance in Parliament since taking office.
item.description: Supporters of President Hassan Rouhani won more seats in parliamentary runoffs, but failing to gain a majority limits their ability for significant reforms.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: ISIS Says It Killed Bangladesh Tailor Once Jailed for Blasphemy
item.description: Islamist militants claimed responsibility for the latest of several fatal attacks in Bangladesh, but officials said was too early to settle on a motive.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GEETA ANAND

item.title: U.N. Renews Mission in Western Sahara in Divisive Vote
item.description: A Security Council resolution renewed the peacekeeping mission but exerted little pressure on Morocco, which expelled dozens of United Nations workers last month.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Rejects Iran’s Protest on Asset Ruling
item.description: The State Department said a Supreme Court ruling allowing use of Iranian assets to compensate victims of terrorist attacks comports with international law.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Ending Impasse, Irish Leaders Agree on a Government
item.description: The agreement, which follows an inconclusive election and two months of political deadlock, is likely to result in the re-election of Edna Kenny as prime minister.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Former Auschwitz Guard Apologizes at Trial in Germany
item.media:description: Reinhold Hanning is on trial in a German court on charges of being an accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people.
item.description: The 94-year-old defendant, Reinhold Hanning, told a German court he was “ashamed I witnessed injustice and allowed it to continue” while serving at the Nazi death camp.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Notes From Aleppo: Intimate Glimpses of War-Ravaged Syria
item.description: Declan Walsh of The Times is on the ground in the most populous Syrian city, observing a civil war’s toll on soldiers and civilians alike.

item.title: Surge in Palestinian Youths in Prison Tests Israel’s Justice System
item.media:description: Dima al-Wawi, center, next to her mother, Sabha, checking Facebook after her release from an Israeli prison, at the family’s home on Sunday in the West Bank town of Halhoul.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: Dima al-Wawi, a 12-year-old jailed for two months for planning to stab an Israeli soldier, was one of hundreds of Palestinian children jailed since attacks on Israelis surged.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Joe Biden Speaks About Faith and Curing Cancer at the Vatican
item.media:description: Pope Francis with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at the Vatican on Friday.
item.media:credit: L'Osservatore Romano, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The vice president’s attendance at a Vatican-sponsored conference on regenerative medicine was a confluence of his embrace of science and faith.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Green Beret Who Beat Up Afghan Officer for Raping Boy Can Stay in Army
item.description: The Army made the decision after lawmakers called for the full reinstatement of Sgt. First Class Charles Martland, who helped beat up the commander in 2011.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Pentagon Details Chain of Errors in Strike on Afghan Hospital
item.media:description: An employee of Doctors Without Borders in October 2015 inside what remained of the organization’s hospital, destroyed in an airstrike that left 42 people dead.
item.description: A report more than 3,000 pages long describes the errors that led to the 2015 strike in Kunduz that killed 42 people. Sixteen American officers have been punished.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Appear Underwhelmed by Under Armour Knockoff
item.media:description: Under Armour has been on a roll in China, with sales nearly tripling in the first three months of this year from a year earlier.
item.description: A flashy rollout by Uncle Martian, with its nearly identical logo of the American sports manufacturer, has been met by skepticism on the Internet in China.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: He Said He Was 17, but High School Basketball Player May Be Closer to 30
item.media:description: Jonathan Nicola, center, in a basketball game in January.
item.description: A student and standout athlete who immigrated from South Sudan to Canada was arrested after it was revealed that he misrepresented his age.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: 2 Charged With Aiding Brussels Attacks Suspect Appear in London Court
item.media:description: Mohamed Abrini
item.description: They are thought to have handed more than $4,300 to Mohamed Abrini, the “man in the hat” believed to have accompanied two suicide bombers to Brussels Airport.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Helicopter Crashes Off Norway, Leaving No Signs of Survivors
item.description: The 13 people on board were en route from the Gullfaks B oil platform in the North Sea, and a land and sea search has recovered 11 bodies.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: A New Generation’s Anger Resounds From a Packed Plaza in Paris
item.media:description: Protesters at the Place de la République in Paris on Thursday, before clashes with the police broke out.
item.description: Nuit Debout, a movement ignited over a plan to change French labor laws, has expanded to include a mélange of grievances, and politicians are warily watching.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Forging a Path for Women, Deep Into India’s Sacred Shrines
item.media:description: “God doesn’t discriminate between men and women, why should religion?” TRUPTI DESAI
item.description: Trupti Desai has emerged at the forefront of a growing campaign for gender equality in religion, leading women into the holy sanctums of temples, often in the face of attacks.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: U.S. Denounces Chinese Law Restricting Foreign Organizations
item.media:description: Chinese officials in Beijing on Thursday before an announcement about new restrictions for foreign nongovernmental organizations.
item.description: Statements critical of the measure, which was passed on Thursday, reflected disappointment that China did not make more changes to previous drafts.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Europe’s Economy, After 8-Year Detour, Is Fitfully Back on Track
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrated against unemployment in front of the Greek Parliament in Athens this month.
item.description: The eurozone, the 19 countries that use the euro, has finally edged back above its precrisis level, but doubts persist about its prospects.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Refugee Held on Nauru Dies After Self-Immolation to Protest Australian Policy
item.media:description: People protesting Australia’s offshore detention centers outside the offices of the Department of Immigration and Border Protection in Sydney, Australia, on Friday.
item.description: The man, a 23-year-old Iranian kept from Australia, was airlifted to a hospital there, where he died from his injuries, the immigration department said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Building Collapses in Kenyan Capital, Killing at Least 10
item.description: The collapse happened during heavy rains in Nairobi, and rescuers said they were searching for survivors trapped in the rubble.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: North Korea Sentences American to 10 Years for Spying, Reports Say
item.media:description: Kim Dong-chul was escorted to his sentencing in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Friday. He had previously apologized for trying to steal military secrets in collusion with South Koreans.
item.description: Kim Dong-chul is the latest United States citizen to receive a harsh sentence in North Korea, which often uses the fates of held Americans as leverage.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Opinion: A Mine vs. a Million Monarchs
item.description: A Mexican conglomerate wants to revive mining in a protected reserve for monarch butterflies.
item.dc:creator: DAN FAGIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The First Global Terrorists Were Anarchists in the 1890s
item.media:description: The funeral of Martial Bourdin, as depicted in the French media.
item.description: And then as now, migrants and civil liberties paid the price.
item.dc:creator: MAYA JASANOFF

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Afghan Women: What the West Gets Wrong
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Defeating cruelty requires a homegrown agenda.
item.dc:creator: BINA SHAH

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
